ol.li: Understand the definition of \R^n, and how to use \R^n to label points.
Draw a picture of the solution set of a system of equations in two or three variables.
Use augmented matrices to solve systems of equations.

subsection.title: Preliminaries: line, plane, space, etc.
subsection.p: We use \R to denote the set of all real numbers, i.e., the number line. This contains numbers like 0, \frac 32, -\pi, 104, \ldots

statement.p: Let n be a positive whole number. We define \R^n = \text{all ordered $n$-tuples of real numbers }(x_1,x_2,x_3,\ldots,x_n).

subsection.p: In other words, \R^n is just the set of all (ordered) lists of n real numbers. We will draw pictures of \R^n in a moment, but keep in mind that this is the definition. For example, (0, \frac 32, -\pi) is an element of \R^3.

example.p: When n=1, we just get \R back: \R^1=\R. Geometrically, this is the number line.
When n=2, we can think of \R^2 as the xy-plane. We can do so because every point on the plane can be represented by an ordered pair of real numebrs, namely, its x- and y-coordinates.
Note that we use the elements of \R^2 to label the points of the plane, but \R^2 is not defined to be the plane.

When n=3, we can think of \R^3 as the space we (appear to) live in. We can do so because every point in space can be represented by an ordered triple of real numebrs, namely, its x-, y-, and z-coordinates.
Again, we can use the elements of \R^3 to label points in space, but \R^3 is not defined to be space!

All colors you can see can be described by three quantities: the amount of red, green, and blue light in that color. (Humans are trichromatic.) So we can also think of \R^3 as the space of all colors.
Again, we can use the elements of \R^3 to label the colors, but \R^3 is not defined to be the set of all visible colors!
In , we could have used \R^4 to label the amount of traffic (x,y,z,w) passing through four streets.
Again, we can use the elements of \R^3 to label points in space, but \R^3 is not defined to be space!

subsection.p: So what is \R^4? or \R^5? or \R^n? These are harder to visualize, so you have to go back to the definition: \R^n is the set of all ordered n-tuples of real numbers (x_1,x_2,x_3,\ldots,x_n).
They are still "geometric" spaces, in the sense that our intuition for \R^2 and \R^3 often extends to \R^n.
We will make definitions and state theorems that apply to any \R^n, but we will only draw pictures for \R^2 and \R^3.

subsection.title: Solutions of Linear Equations: Pictures
subsection.p: In this subsection, we consider some simple systems of linear equations, and we draw their solutions.

paragraphs.title: One Linear Equation
paragraphs.p: Consider the equation x+y=1. The solution set is the set of all pairs (x,y) that satisfy this equation. Rewriting, this is the same as all solutions to y = 1-x. This is a line in the plane.

The equation x+y=1 (or y=1-x) is called the implicit equation of the line. Any point on the line has the form (x,y) = (t,\,1-t) for some real number t. This is called the parametric form of the line; in this case, t is the parameter.

remark.p: For our purposes, a line is a ray that is straight and infinite in both directions.

paragraphs.p: Now consider the equation x+y+z=1. The set of all solutions (x,y,z) of this implicit equation form a plane in space. Any point on this plane has the form (x,y,z) = (t,\,w,\,1-t-w) for some values t,w in \R. This is the parametric form of the plane; in this case, t and w are the parameters.

figure.caption: As t and w vary, the parametric equation (x,y,z)=(t,\,w,\,1-t-w) sweeps out the plane defined by the implicit equation x+y+z=1.

remark.p: A plane is a flat sheet that is infinite in all directions.

paragraphs.p: What happens when there are more than three variables? We will see that x+y+z+w=1 defines a "3-plane" in \R^4. In general, a nonzero linear equation in n variables defines an "(n-1)-space" in \R^n.

paragraphs.title: Multiple linear equations

statement.p: A system of equations is called inconsistent if it has no solutions. It is called consistent otherwise.

subsection.title: Solving Systems of Equations

ul.li: A solution to a system of equations is a list of numbers x, y, z, \ldots that make all of the equations true simultaneously.
The solution set of a system of equations is the collection of all solutions.
Solving the system means describing the solution set parametrically.

subsection.p: A solution to a system of equations in n variables is a list of n numbers: it is an element of \R^n. For example, (x,y,z) = (1,-2,3) is a solution to ; this is an element of \R^3.

paragraphs.title: The elimination method
Augmented Matrices and Row Operations

remark.p: The process of doing row operations to a matrix does not change the solution set of the corresponding linear equations!
Indeed, the whole point of doing these operations is to solve the equations using the elimination method.

statement.p: Two matrices are called row equivalent if one can be obtained from the other by doing some number of elementary row operations.

paragraphs.p: So the linear equations of row-equivalent matrices have the same solution set.

statement.p: A system of equations is called inconsistent if it has no solutions. It is called consistent otherwise.
